elements.content: Three new heterometallic metal organic frameworks, [{[Ca6(H2O)18]­[Ag6(mna)6]2}­·[Ag6(Hmna)6]­·20H2O], 1, {[Sr3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·12H2O}, 2, and {[Ba3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 3, have been synthesized following hard–soft acids–bases principle. Compounds 1 and 2 have three-dimensional structures with cor and pcu (α-Po) topology, whereas compound 3 has a two-dimensional sql topology. Smaller calcium and strontium ions form a simple dimer (Ca2/Sr2, 1/2) and tetramer units (Sr4, 2), whereas the larger barium ion forms infinite Ba–O–Ba chains. The presence of the electron-rich mna ligand in all the compounds paved the way for the detection of electron-deficient hazardous nitroaromatics employing photoluminescence quenching methods. The luminescence intensities of the compounds are strongly quenched by picric acid, p-nitro phenol, and 2-nitro toluene at low concentration, which indicates that these compounds are excellent materials for the detection of these nitroaromatics in solution.

elements.content: Examples of inorganic coordination polymers (CPs) stabilized using single metal ion connected through the organic linkers are ubiquitous. Metal oxo-clusters have also been incorporated as part of such structures, the famous examples being MOF-5, MIL-100, etc. Attempts were made with reasonable success at the incorporation of well-known poly-oxo metal ions such as Keggin, Anderson, etc. We have been interested in exploring the hard–soft acids–bases (HSAB) principle for rationally synthesizing new hybrid compounds. Many hybrid compounds, reported in the literature, use the oxygen from the carboxylic acids and nitrogen from the pyridine based ligands for the assembly of new structures. From the HSAB theory, oxygen would be a harder base compared to nitrogen and sulfur, and their binding behavior in many of the compounds reflect this difference well.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Examples of inorganic coordination polymers (CPs) stabilized using single metal ion connected through the organic linkers are ubiquitous. Metal oxo-clusters have also been incorporated as part of such structures, the famous examples being MOF-5, MIL-100, etc. Attempts were made with reasonable success at the incorporation of well-known poly-oxo metal ions such as Keggin, Anderson, etc. We have been interested in exploring the hard-soft acids-bases (HSAB) principle for rationally synthesizing new hybrid compounds. Many hybrid compounds, reported in the literature, use the oxygen from the carboxylic acids and nitrogen from the pyridine based ligands for the assembly of new structures. From the HSAB theory, oxygen would be a harder base compared to nitrogen and sulfur, and their binding behavior in many of the compounds reflect this difference well.

elements.content: We have been interested in exploring the 2-mercapto nicotinic acid (H2mna) which provides three possible binding sites (S, N, O) with different basicities. Ideally, one would employ softer bases such as N and S to react initially with softer acids (Ag+, Cu+, etc.) followed by the harder acids to bind with the oxygen (). In principle, this appears to be a simple and useful approach, and there have been some studies in this direction. Our earlier attempts with H2mna realized the formation of the metalloligand [M6(Hmna)6] (M = Cu, Ag), which on further reaction with the transition metal resulted in interesting structures. We were also successful in reacting sequentially utilizing the differences in the basic nature of the three binding sites, S, N, and O. During the course of the study, we have successfully stabilized M6 (M = Ag, Cu) octahedral metalloligand cluster stabilized by noncovalent interactions. These metalloligands have strong fluorescence behavior, and they have six carboxylate groups available for binding with the secondary metal ion. Recently metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on alkaline earth metal ions have drawn attention due to their high thermal stability and applications in gas adsorption, proton conduction, and heterogeneous catalysis. The successful synthesis and characterization of transition metal linked Ag6 octahedral cluster prompted the exploration of the reactivity of this cluster with alkaline earth metal ions. We believe that the alkaline metal ions would have strong binding affinity toward carboxylate groups. In addition, they have closed shell electronic configurations, which may not take part in the luminescence behavior of the metalloligand and provide opportunities to evaluate the metalloligand’s usefulness.

elements.content: In the present investigation, we have employed the hexanuclear metalloligand, [Ag6(mna)6]6– (), formed using S and N binding sites from the 2-mercapto nicotinic acid, to react with alkaline earth metal ions forming three new compounds. Thus, [{[Ca6(H2O)18]­[Ag6(mna)6]2}­·[Ag6(Hmna)6]­·20H2O], 1, {[Sr3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·12H2O, 2, and {[Ba3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 3, have been synthesized and characterized. In this paper, the synthesis, structure and the possible applications in nitroaromatic explosives detection are presented.

In this paper, the synthesis, structure and the possible applications in nitroaromatic explosives detection are presented.

elements.content:
The chemicals, Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O, Sr­(NO3)2, Ba­(NO3)2, aqueous NH3 (25%), and ethanol, were purchased from SDfine (India). AgNO3 and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (H2mna) were acquired from Sigma–Aldrich.

Synthesis

Compounds 1–3 were prepared following a sequential crystallization. Thus, the hexanuclear metalloligand [Ag6(mna)6]6– was prepared using the reported procedure followed by the slow diffusion of alkaline earth metal ion solution.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The chemicals, Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O, Sr(NO3)2, Ba(NO3)2, aqueous NH3 (25%), and ethanol, were purchased from SDfine (India). AgNO3 and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (H2mna) were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich.

Synthesis

Compounds 1-3 were prepared following a sequential crystallization. Thus, the hexanuclear metalloligand [Ag6(mna)6]6- was prepared using the reported procedure followed by the slow diffusion of alkaline earth metal ion solution.

The pale yellow precipitate that formed was dissolved by the addition of few drops of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ag6(mna)6]6- Metalloligand

(Solution A) A mixture of AgNO3 (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (0.031 g, 0.2 mmol) in 2 mL of water was sonicated at room temperature for 20 min. The pale yellow precipitate that formed was dissolved by the addition of few drops of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution.

elements.content: (Solution B) Ca­(NO3)2­·4H2O (0.047 g, 0.2 mmol)/Sr­(NO3)2 (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) or Ba­(NO3)2 (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) was taken in a 2 mL water/ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1) for the synthesis of the respective compound.

Preparation of Alkaline Earth Metal Ion Solution

(Solution B) Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.047 g, 0.2 mmol)/Sr(NO3)2 (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) or Ba(NO3)2 (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) was taken in a 2 mL water/ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1) for the synthesis of the respective compound.

elements.content: In a test tube 2 mL of solution B was carefully layered on top of 2 mL of solution A. The test tube was sealed using parafilm and kept undisturbed for 48 h at room temperature, which resulted in large quantity of block-shaped crystals. The crystals were carefully harvested and washed with a mixture of H2O/EtOH and stored at room temperature for further characterizations. Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 1: C 23.04, H 2.43, N 4.48, S 10.25; found: C 23.54, H 2.58, N 4.74, S 10.47; 2: C 19.43, H 2.81, N 3.78, S 8.65; found: C 19.78, H 2.52, N 4.11, S 8.23; 3: C 18.78, H 2.36, N 3.65, S 8.36; found: C 18.30, H 2.27, N 3.73, S 8.30.

elements.content: Initial characterizations were carried out by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectroscopy (IR), UV–Vis spectroscopy, photoluminescence studies (PL), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The PXRD data were recorded in the 2θ range 5–50° using Cu Kα radiation (Philips X’pert). The observed PXRD patterns for all the compounds were found to be consistent with the PXRD patterns simulated from the single crystal structure study (Supporting Information, Figure S1). UV–Vis and photoluminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 and PerkinElmer LS 55 spectrophotometer, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (Metler–Toledo) was carried out in oxygen atmosphere (flow rate = 40 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 10 °C/min) (Supporting Information, Figure S2). IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets using PerkinElmer Frontier FTIR spectrometer (Supporting Information, Figure S3). A broad band in the region of ∼3200–3500 cm–1, suggested the presence of a number of water molecules. Aromatic C–H stretching, aromatic CC stretching, and CO stretching were observed in the region of ∼2900–3100 cm–1, ∼1540–1560 cm–1, and ∼1560–1640 cm–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization Techniques

Initial characterizations were carried out by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectroscopy (IR), UV-Vis spectroscopy, photoluminescence studies (PL), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The PXRD data were recorded in the 2θ range 5-50° using Cu Kα radiation (Philips X'pert). The observed PXRD patterns for all the compounds were found to be consistent with the PXRD patterns simulated from the single crystal structure study (Supporting Information, Figure S1). UV-Vis and photoluminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 and PerkinElmer LS 55 spectrophotometer, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (Metler-Toledo) was carried out in oxygen atmosphere (flow rate = 40 mL/min) in the temperature range 30-800 °C (heating rate = 10 °C/min) (Supporting Information, Figure S2). IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets using PerkinElmer Frontier FTIR spectrometer (Supporting Information, Figure S3). A broad band in the region of ~3200-3500 cm-1, suggested the presence of a number of water molecules. Aromatic C-H stretching, aromatic CC stretching, and CO stretching were observed in the region of ~2900-3100 cm-1, ~1540-1560 cm-1, and ~1560-1640 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: Single crystal diffraction data for all the compounds were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 35 mA using Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The data reduction was carried out using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All the structure were solved and refined using SHELXL97, present in the WINGX package of programs (Version1.63.04a). The aromatic C–H hydrogen atoms are located and assigned from the difference Fourier map. The hydrogen atom positions of the coordinated and lattice water molecules for the compounds 1 and 3 and the lattice water molecules of compound 2 could not be located from the difference Fourier map. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules in compound 2 were assigned using the SHELX97 program. The full matrix least-squares refinement against |F 2| was performed using WinGx package of programs. The highly disordered solvent molecules in compound 1 and 3 were accounted for by using the SQUEEZE option present in the WinGX platon program. The final refinements included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. The details of the structure solution and final refinement parameters are listed in . The CCDC numbers for the compounds 1, 2, and 3 are 1451936, 1451937, and 1451938, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal diffraction data for all the compounds were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 35 mA using Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The data reduction was carried out using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All the structure were solved and refined using SHELXL97, present in the WINGX package of programs (Version1.63.04a). The aromatic C-H hydrogen atoms are located and assigned from the difference Fourier map. The hydrogen atom positions of the coordinated and lattice water molecules for the compounds 1 and 3 and the lattice water molecules of compound 2 could not be located from the difference Fourier map. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules in compound 2 were assigned using the SHELX97 program. The full matrix least-squares refinement against |F 2| was performed using WinGx package of programs. The highly disordered solvent molecules in compound 1 and 3 were accounted for by using the SQUEEZE option present in the WinGX platon program. The final refinements included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. The details of the structure solution and final refinement parameters are listed in . The CCDC numbers for the compounds 1, 2, and 3 are 1451936, 1451937, and 1451938, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The hexanuclear silver based metalloligand with six mna ligands has been isolated before. The [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster has Ag–N and Ag–S average bond distances of 2.291 and 2.337 Å, respectively (Supporting Information, Table S1). The Ag···Ag distances are in the range of 2.946(1)–3.379(1) Å (Supporting Information, Table S1), which suggest argentophilic interactions and are comparable to the reported values. In 1, we observed two types of hexameric silver clusters, the neutral, [Ag6(Hmna)6] and the anionic [Ag6(mna)6]6– clusters. The anionic [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster binds with the Ca2+ ions through the carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, three carboxylate units bond with six Ca2+ ions via both the oxygen atoms, while the remaining three carboxylates connect to three Ca2+ ions via one oxygen atoms and leads to a μ9-η2:η2:η2:η1η1:η1 binding mode (a). Each Ca2+ ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1(#2), O2, O3) and three coordinated water molecules (O5, O6, O7) forming a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S4a). The Ca–O bond distances are in the range 2.307(7)–2.580(8) Å (av. 2.405 Å) (Table S1, Supporting Information), which is comparable with other reported calcium carboxylate compounds. Two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1) bridge a pair of Ca2+ ions, forming a Ca2 dimer unit with Ca–Ca distance of 3.978 Å (Supporting Information, Figure S4b). Each [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster is connected to six Ca2 dimer units, whereas each Ca2 dimer is connected to four cluster units. Considering the connectivity from the carboxylate groups of [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster, we find that five carboxylate units are connected with five Ca2 dimer units. This connectivity leads to a two-dimensional layer. The sixth carboxylate group from the [Ag6(mna)6]6– unit is connected to a Ca2 dimer of the nearby layer forming a three-dimensional structure of 1 (c). From a topological view, the connectivity between Ca2 dimer and [Ag6(mna)6]6– unit would gives rise to a (4,6) binodal net which is similar to the Corundum, Al2O3, net (b). A TOPOS analysis indicates that this is cor topology (corundum structure) with a point (Schlafli) symbol of (43.63)3(46.69)2. In compound 1, each layer repeats itself after four such arrangements (Supporting Information, Figure S5). This, possibly, explains the large “c” parameter observed in this compound. The neutral Ag6 cluster, [Ag6(Hmna)6], units are found to occupy space in between the layers, and the nearby space is occupied by the lattice and coordinated water molecules (Supporting Information, Figure S6). The presence of a number of mna units in close proximity leads to π···π as well as C–H···π interactions. The large number of extra-framework and coordinated water molecules may participate in hydrogen bond interactions among themselves, which could not be evaluated as it was not possible to locate all the hydrogen atoms.

Results and Discussion

Structure of [{[Ca6(H2O)18][Ag6(mna)6]2}⋅[Ag6(Hmna)6]⋅20H2O], 1 

The hexanuclear silver based metalloligand with six mna ligands has been isolated before. The [Ag6(mna)6]6- cluster has Ag-N and Ag-S average bond distances of 2.291 and 2.337 Å, respectively (Supporting Information, Table S1). The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances are in the range of 2.946(1)-3.379(1) Å (Supporting Information, Table S1), which suggest argentophilic interactions and are comparable to the reported values. In 1, we observed two types of hexameric silver clusters, the neutral, [Ag6(Hmna)6] and the anionic [Ag6(mna)6]6- clusters. The anionic [Ag6(mna)6]6- cluster binds with the Ca2+ ions through the carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, three carboxylate units bond with six Ca2+ ions via both the oxygen atoms, while the remaining three carboxylates connect to three Ca2+ ions via one oxygen atoms and leads to a μ9-η2:η2:η2:η1η1:η1 binding mode (a). Each Ca2+ ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1(#2), O2, O3) and three coordinated water molecules (O5, O6, O7) forming a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S4a). The Ca-O bond distances are in the range 2.307(7)-2.580(8) Å (av. 2.405 Å) (Table S1, Supporting Information), which is comparable with other reported calcium carboxylate compounds. Two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1) bridge a pair of Ca2+ ions, forming a Ca2 dimer unit with Ca-Ca distance of 3.978 Å (Supporting Information, Figure S4b). Each [Ag6(mna)6]6- cluster is connected to six Ca2 dimer units, whereas each Ca2 dimer is connected to four cluster units. Considering the connectivity from the carboxylate groups of [Ag6(mna)6]6- cluster, we find that five carboxylate units are connected with five Ca2 dimer units. This connectivity leads to a two-dimensional layer. The sixth carboxylate group from the [Ag6(mna)6]6- unit is connected to a Ca2 dimer of the nearby layer forming a three-dimensional structure of 1 (c). From a topological view, the connectivity between Ca2 dimer and [Ag6(mna)6]6- unit would gives rise to a (4,6) binodal net which is similar to the Corundum, Al2O3, net (b). A TOPOS analysis indicates that this is cor topology (corundum structure) with a point (Schlafli) symbol of (43.63)3(46.69)2. In compound 1, each layer repeats itself after four such arrangements (Supporting Information, Figure S5). This, possibly, explains the large "c" parameter observed in this compound. The neutral Ag6 cluster, [Ag6(Hmna)6], units are found to occupy space in between the layers, and the nearby space is occupied by the lattice and coordinated water molecules (Supporting Information, Figure S6). The presence of a number of mna units in close proximity leads to π⋅⋅⋅π as well as C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. The large number of extra-framework and coordinated water molecules may participate in hydrogen bond interactions among themselves, which could not be evaluated as it was not possible to locate all the hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: The [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster in 2 also has comparable Ag–N and Ag–S average bond distances (2.299 and 2.488 Å) (Supporting Information, Table S1). Argentophilic interactions with Ag···Ag distances of 2.909(1)–3.341(1) Å (Supporting Information, Table S1) is also observed. All the six carboxylate groups of the hexameric [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster binds with Sr2+ ions. Thus, three carboxylate units binds with five Sr2+ ion via both the oxygen atoms, while three carboxylate groups binds through one oxygen with three Sr2+ ion. This bonding gives rise to a μ8-η2:η2:η1­:η1:η1:η1 binding mode (a). The three strontium atoms exhibit differences in their coordination environment. Thus, Sr(1) is coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O2(#1), O4, O11) and three coordinated water molecules (O13, O14, O15) forming a distorted square antiprismatic geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S7a); Sr(2) is coordinated by one carboxylate oxygen (O10) and six coordinated water molecules (O16–O21) of which two are bridging (μ2-H2O, O16, O17) forming a monocapped trigonal prismatic geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S7b); and Sr(3) binds with six carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O7, O8, O8(#2), O9, O10), two bridging water molecules (O16, O17) and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O22), forming a tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S7c). The observed Sr–O bond distances are in the range of 2.468(2)–2.847(2) Å, (av. 2.742 Å) (Table S1, Supporting Information), which are comparable to those reported before. The strontium connectivity appears to show interesting features. Thus, Sr(1) is connected via two bridging oxygen (O2), forming Sr2 dimers (Supporting Information, Figure S8a). A Sr4 tetramer is formed by the connectivity between Sr(2)–Sr(3) and Sr(3)–Sr(3) (Supporting Information, Figure S8b) through O10, O16, O17, and two O8 bridges, respectively. The Sr–Sr distances are in the range 3.993(4)–4.344(5) Å. The Sr2 and Sr4 units are connected through the [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster units give rise to a three-dimensionally extended structure (b,c). From a topological point of view, each Sr2 dimer and Sr4 tetramer unit is connected to six [Ag6(mna)6]6– metalloligand, and each metalloligand is connected with three Sr2 and three Sr4 units. This connectivity gives rise to uninodal 6-c net (a). The TOPOS analysis indicates that this structure has pcu α-Po topology with point (Schläfli) symbol (412.63) (b). Related pcu net structure has been observed previously in the sodium salt of [Ag6(mna)6]6– (c). Similar to 1, the close proximity between the mna units gives rise to reasonable C–H···π and π···π interactions. The large number of water molecules, both coordinated and free, would participate in hydrogen-bond interactions.

elements.content: The [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster in 3 has average Ag–N and Ag–S distances of 2.273 and 2.504 Å, respectively, and argentophilic interactions with Ag···Ag contact distances of 2.867(1)–3.487(2) Å (Supporting Information, Table S1). Among the six carboxylate groups of [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster, only four carboxylate groups participate in bonding with Ba2+ ions, and the remaining two are free. The carboxytlate groups are connected with two Ba2+ ions through both the oxygen atoms with a μ8-η2:η2:η2:η2 binding mode (a). One oxygen atom of the bonded carboxylate bridges two Ba2+ ions. The barium ions exhibit differences in the coordination with oxygen atoms. Thus, Ba(1) is eight-coordinated and Ba(2) is 10-coordinated. Barium exhibiting higher coordination is well-known in solid state chemistry. The eight-coordinated barium has three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O5, O6) from two carboxylate groups, three bridging water molecules (μ2-H2O, O8, O10), and two terminal coordinated water molecules (O7, O9) and has a distorted square antiprismatic geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S9a). The 10-coordinated Ba(2), occupying the special position. has six carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5), two μ2-H2O (O10), and two bonded water molecules (O11), adopting a distorted bicapped cubic geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S9b). The Ba–O bond distances are in the range of 2.616(4)–3.233(9) Å (av. 2.854 Å), (Supporting Information, Table S1), which is in agreement with those reported earlier. The barium centers are connected through the carboxylate oxygen atoms and bridging water molecules forming a one-dimensional Ba–O–Ba chain (b). The Ba–Ba separation distances are in the range 4.304(3) Å–4.670(6) Å. Thus, the connectivity between the 1D Ba–O–Ba chains and [Ag6(mna)6]6– metalloligand clusters gives rise to a two-dimensional layer (c). The layers are stacked one over the other in an AAAA··· fashion (Supporting Information, Figure S10). For a topological analysis, the Ba(1), Ba(2), and [Ag6(mna)6]6– can be considered as three different nodes, which would result in a trinodal 4,6,8-c net with stoichiometry (4-c)­2­(6-c)­(8-c) with a new topology (Supporting Information, Figure S11a). The point (Schläfli) symbol for this net is (34.42.)2­(34.44.54.63)­(36.48.54.68.72). Considering Ba(2) and [Ag6(mna)6]6– as two different nodes, the structure gives a 4-c uninodal net. A TOPOS analysis indicates that this is sql topology with point (Schlafli) symbol of (44.62) (Supporting Information, Figure S11b). The lattice as well as coordinated water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms take part in hydrogen bond interactions. In addition, both C–H···π and π···π interactions involving the mna ligand have also been observed (Supporting Information, Figure S12).

elements.content: The metalloligand octahedral cluster [Ag6(mna)6]6– has been linked with alkaline earth elements giving rise to new compounds having different dimensionalities. Earlier, [Ag6(mna)6]6– and [Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]4– have been shown to assemble with transition metals giving rise to interesting structures. The synthesis of these compounds was carried out employing a layering approach at room temperature, which resulted in a number of coordinated and lattice water molecules. The presence of a large number of water molecules appears to have a bearing on the final structure. Thus, the more the number of water molecules, the lower is the dimensionality of the structure. Another way to understand the formation of these compounds is to look at it through the salt formation analogy. It is known that the metal ions in solutions have water molecules loosely bound in the first coordination sphere. During the salt formation, the incoming ligand ions have to dislodge the water molecules to bind with the metal ion forming ionic solids. There have been attempts in understanding the formation of such compounds, both theoretically as well as experimentally. The present synthesis was carried out predominantly in aqueous phase, and the large anion, [Ag6(mna)6]6–, needs to dislodge all the water molecules to bind the alkaline earth metal ion. During this process, it needs to gain either six protons or lose six electrons to bind with the metal centers. The presence of a number of coordinated water molecules in the present structure clearly suggests that the metalloligand anion is either not strong enough or hindered sterically to remove all the water molecules from the coordination sphere of the metal ion. In addition, we also observed the presence of a neutral metalloligand, [Ag6(Hmna)6], in 1, which also suggests the anion gaining the protons preferably from the water molecule rather than the metal ions from solution. Another observation made during the present synthesis is the difficulty in preparing a phase pure solid (by PXRD) of the reported compounds. There appears to be a number of closely related structures that are formed under the synthetic conditions. All these observations clearly suggest that the present compound needs to be considered as an intermediate or metastable one. Many careful attempts were needed to obtain the phase pure compounds reported in the present study (PXRD, Supporting Information, Figure S1). It is too early to either predict or formulate a suitable mechanism for the formation of these solids as it involves the stabilization of a larger octahedral metalloligand as part of the lattice. Similar observations have been made during the stabilization of polyoxometalates where subtle pH changes lead to different nuclearity of the species.

Structural Comparison

The metalloligand octahedral cluster [Ag6(mna)6]6- has been linked with alkaline earth elements giving rise to new compounds having different dimensionalities. Earlier, [Ag6(mna)6]6- and [Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]4- have been shown to assemble with transition metals giving rise to interesting structures. The synthesis of these compounds was carried out employing a layering approach at room temperature, which resulted in a number of coordinated and lattice water molecules. The presence of a large number of water molecules appears to have a bearing on the final structure. Thus, the more the number of water molecules, the lower is the dimensionality of the structure. Another way to understand the formation of these compounds is to look at it through the salt formation analogy. It is known that the metal ions in solutions have water molecules loosely bound in the first coordination sphere. During the salt formation, the incoming ligand ions have to dislodge the water molecules to bind with the metal ion forming ionic solids. There have been attempts in understanding the formation of such compounds, both theoretically as well as experimentally. The present synthesis was carried out predominantly in aqueous phase, and the large anion, [Ag6(mna)6]6-, needs to dislodge all the water molecules to bind the alkaline earth metal ion. During this process, it needs to gain either six protons or lose six electrons to bind with the metal centers. The presence of a number of coordinated water molecules in the present structure clearly suggests that the metalloligand anion is either not strong enough or hindered sterically to remove all the water molecules from the coordination sphere of the metal ion. In addition, we also observed the presence of a neutral metalloligand, [Ag6(Hmna)6], in 1, which also suggests the anion gaining the protons preferably from the water molecule rather than the metal ions from solution. Another observation made during the present synthesis is the difficulty in preparing a phase pure solid (by PXRD) of the reported compounds. There appears to be a number of closely related structures that are formed under the synthetic conditions. All these observations clearly suggest that the present compound needs to be considered as an intermediate or metastable one. Many careful attempts were needed to obtain the phase pure compounds reported in the present study (PXRD, Supporting Information, Figure S1). It is too early to either predict or formulate a suitable mechanism for the formation of these solids as it involves the stabilization of a larger octahedral metalloligand as part of the lattice. Similar observations have been made during the stabilization of polyoxometalates where subtle pH changes lead to different nuclearity of the species.

elements.content: The usefulness of [Ag6(mna)6]6– has been examined earlier as a part of an antibacterial and antifungal studies. A careful examination of the reported structure with the present one reveals some similarities. For example, in the reported compound [Ag6(mna)6]6–­·4Na+­·2­[C4O3H12N]+­·10H2O, we find that there are Na4 tetramer clusters which are linked through the carboxylate units of [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster (Supporting Information, Figure S13). In the present study, compound 2 also has Sr4 tetramer units. In addition, the compound 2 also possesses a Sr2 dimer unit. The net connectivity between the Na4 tetramer and [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster exhibits a pcu (α-Po like) arrangement, which is also observed in compound 2 based on the connectivity involving Sr4, Sr2, and [Ag6(mna)6]6– clusters ().

elements.content: In the present structures, calcium and strontium containing ones form a 3D structure. The barium, though having the larger ionic size, forms a 2D structure. A careful examination of the structures reveals that the calcium and strontium form dimer (Ca2) and dimer (Sr2)/linear tetramer (Sr4) units in 1 and 2, respectively, which are bonded with the [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster units. Compound 3, on the other hand, forms a one-dimensional Ba–O–Ba chains that are connected to the [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster forming the 2D structure. The large size of the Ba2+ ions resulted in the Ba–O–Ba linkages, and the [Ag6(mna)6]6– cluster could experience some steric strain, which results in a lower dimensional structure. More examples may be required to verify this hypothesis, especially with other large cations such as lanthanides.

elements.content: The UV–Vis absorption spectra of compounds have been recorded at room temperature in the solid state. All the compounds exhibit absorption bands in the region of 200–500 nm (Supporting Information, Figure S14). The various observed bands correspond to the intraligand π → π* transitions of the mna ligand. Similar absorption bands have been observed for the free H2mna ligand also (Supporting Information, Figure S14). We have also made estimation of the optical band gap in the compounds, which suggested band gap energy values lie in the range of 2.64–2.76 eV (Supporting Information, Figure S15). The band gap energies as determined by the Tauc plots, are very close to that for the metalloligand [Ag6(mna)6]6– (2.73 eV) and free H2mna ligand (2.75 eV). This implies that the electronic states of the compounds are close to the metalloligand, which could be due to the closed shell electronic configuration of the divalent alkaline earth metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Visible and Photoluminescence Spectroscopy Studies

The UV-Vis absorption spectra of compounds have been recorded at room temperature in the solid state. All the compounds exhibit absorption bands in the region of 200-500 nm (Supporting Information, Figure S14). The various observed bands correspond to the intraligand π → π* transitions of the mna ligand. Similar absorption bands have been observed for the free H2mna ligand also (Supporting Information, Figure S14). We have also made estimation of the optical band gap in the compounds, which suggested band gap energy values lie in the range of 2.64-2.76 eV (Supporting Information, Figure S15). The band gap energies as determined by the Tauc plots, are very close to that for the metalloligand [Ag6(mna)6]6- (2.73 eV) and free H2mna ligand (2.75 eV). This implies that the electronic states of the compounds are close to the metalloligand, which could be due to the closed shell electronic configuration of the divalent alkaline earth metal ions.

elements.content: The solid state photoluminescence spectra recorded at room temperature (excitation wavelength of 375 nm) exhibited three emission bands around 450, 490, and 530 nm for 1 and 3, while for 2 one emission band at around 535 nm (Supporting Information, Figure S16). The observed bands in the range of 445–490 and 535 nm may due to the intraligand emissions and cluster based ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) mixed with the metal-centered transitions from the Ag6 core (Supporting Information, Figure S16). This assignment compares well with previous reports on compounds based on the [Ag6(mna)6]6– core.

elements.content: Nitroaromatic compounds have been classified as potential explosives. There has been considerable interest to detect such compounds employing simpler approaches. Photoluminescence-based detection of nitroaromatics offers a sensitive and easier method because nitroaromatics act as a fluorescence quencher due to their electron accepting ability. In recent times, the MOFs and CPs have been explored as possible candidates for nitroaromatic sensing with reasonable success. It appears that the usefulness of MOFs or CPs for nitroaromatic detection is based on the balance between the electron donating and electron accepting nature of the participating ligands. Though much of the studies of the detection of nitroaromatics concentrates on Zn2+ and Cd2+ containing MOFs, the studies on alkaline earth metal ions are relatively less.
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatics Sensing

Nitroaromatic compounds have been classified as potential explosives. There has been considerable interest to detect such compounds employing simpler approaches. Photoluminescence-based detection of nitroaromatics offers a sensitive and easier method because nitroaromatics act as a fluorescence quencher due to their electron accepting ability. In recent times, the MOFs and CPs have been explored as possible candidates for nitroaromatic sensing with reasonable success. It appears that the usefulness of MOFs or CPs for nitroaromatic detection is based on the balance between the electron donating and electron accepting nature of the participating ligands. Though much of the studies of the detection of nitroaromatics concentrates on Zn2+ and Cd2+ containing MOFs, the studies on alkaline earth metal ions are relatively less.

elements.content: In the present study, we have explored the possible utility of the compounds for nitroaromatic sensing studies. The observation of a strong emission around 530 nm (λex = 375 nm) in all the compounds suggests that these compounds could be employed for nitroaromatics sensing. To investigate the fluorescence properties, a 10 mM dispersed solution of MOF 1–3 was prepared by adding finely ground MOF samples to methanol solvent and stirring for about 30 min. Subsequently 2.5 mL of this solution was taken in a fluorescence cuvette of 1 cm path length. All the fluorescence spectra were recorded in situ after incremental addition of 10 mM of the freshly prepared nitro aromatics solution in methanol, upon excitation at 375 nm. The quenching efficiency (%) was calculated using the formula {(I 0 – I)/I 0} × 100 (%), in which I 0 is the initial emission intensity and I is the intensity after the addition of nitro aromatics (50 μL, 10 mM). In order to investigate the stability of the present compounds in the presence of nitroaromatics, we soaked the compounds in picric acid (PA) solution for 24 h and washed with methanol. The PXRD patterns recorded before and after the soaking suggested the compounds retain the structural integrity (Supporting Information, Figure S17). The excitation spectra of one of the compounds, compound 2, did not exhibit any significant difference before and after treating with p-nitro phenol (PNP) (Supporting Information, Figure S18). This also suggests that the compound is stable. The commonly investigated nitroaromatics in the literature are picric acid, nitro phenols, and nitro toluenes. In the present study, PA, PNP, and 2-nitro toluene (2-NT) have been taken for the nitroaromatic sensing studies. The compounds appears to exhibit good sensing behavior as the emission band loses the intensity on the addition of the nitroaromatics (, , and ), suggesting that they may be good candidates for the nitroaromatics sensing in solution, especially in small concentrations (μM). Of the three compounds, compound 1 is the most sensitive toward this behavior with the emission band at 530 nm, which appears to be quenched more than 95% of its original intensity at very low analyte concentrations ( and ).

Of the three compounds, compound 1 is the most sensitive toward this behavior with the emission band at 530 nm, which appears to be quenched more than 95% of its original intensity at very low analyte concentrations ( and ).

elements.content: Determination of Stern–Volmer constant (K sv) is essential as it is related to the quenching rate. To calculate the quenching constant, the titration results with PA, PNP, and 2-NT are treated with the Stern–Volmer equation at low concentration, I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q], where I 0 is the initial emission intensity and I is the intensity after the addition of analyte and [Q] is the concentration of the analyte. For compounds 1–3, at lower analyte concentrations the Stern–Volmer plots follow linearity, while it deviates from linearity on increased analyte concentration (Supporting Information, Figure S19). The linear part at low analyte concentration is due to the static quenching, where the analytes interact with the sensor (MOFs) to form a non-emissive ground state complex. The nonlinearity arises due to the dynamic or collisional quenching, where the electron or energy transfer occurs from the excited state of the sensor (MOFs) to the analyte. The quenching constants (K sv) are estimated by fitting the linear part in the Stern–Volmer plot (). The K sv values are in the range of 45 × 103 to 3 × 103 M–1 for compounds 2–3. The K sv values are high for compound 1 (39 × 104 to 18 × 104). The higher K sv value suggests high sensitivity of compound 1 toward the analyte, viz., PA, PNP, and 2-NT. The recyclability of compounds for nitroaromatic sensing has been checked by using the same compounds repeatedly, which exhibited similar quenching behavior. PA and PNP can also be detected in aqueous media, though the quenching efficiency is less compared to that in methanol solution (Supporting Information, Figure S20).

elements.content: It is known that the luminescent quenching could be due to the photoinduced electron transfer from the electron-rich MOF to the electron-deficient analyte. Such an electron transfer pathway would be feasible only when the LUMO of analytes are close to the band gap of the MOF. We have made attempts to calculate the HOMO–LUMO levels of the nitroaromatics as well as the [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster using the density functional theory at the B3LYP/6-311G + LANL2DZ (for Ag) level (Supporting Information, Figure S21) from the optimized structures using Gaussian 09 suit. We have optimized [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster as this cluster is responsible for the luminescence property of the compounds. The band gap energies for the compounds 1–3 are very close to the band gap of the cluster. Therefore, HOMO–LUMO levels of the nitroaromatics are compared here with HOMO–LUMO levels of the [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster. From the DFT calculations, it is clear that the HOMO of the [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster is higher compared to the LUMO levels of the nitroaromatics; such a situation would facilitate easy electron transfer leading to the quenching processes. The LUMO energies of the nitroaromatics differ due to the different electron deficiency, which leads to higher stability. DFT study indicates that the [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster can also detects the nitroaromatics. We have attempted to investigate the nitroaromatic sensing behavior with the [Ag6(H2mna)6] cluster. The cluster also exhibits sensing behavior toward the nitroaromatics though the quenching efficiency appears less compared to the compounds 1–3 (Supporting Information, Figure S22). It is likely that higher quenching efficiency of the compounds may be due to the rigid nature of the frameworks. Though the HOMO–LUMO energy levels are in a favorable situation, between the host and the analytes, this alone may not be responsible for the observed luminescence quenching behavior. It may be noted that high quenching efficiency has been observed with PNP and 2-NT, though LUMO energies of PNP and 2-NT are higher than PA. The high quenching efficiency exhibited by 2-NT can be explained based on the dipole–dipole interactions between the MOF and 2-NT. It is known that the dipole moment of 2-NT is more compared to PNP or PA. It is likely that the dipole–dipole interactions between the 2-NT and the MOF would aid in enhancing the electron transfer process and increase the quenching efficiency. Similar behavior was observed earlier in MOFs. The high quenching observed for PNP as well as PA may not be explained by simple dipole–dipole interactions. To understand the quenching behavior, we sought to investigate possible excited state energy transfer. The absorption spectra of the nitroaromatics, recorded in methanol, exhibit little overlap with the emission spectra of 1–3 (Supporting Information, Figure S23), suggesting that there may not be any possibility for resonance energy transfer between the MOF and the analyte (PA/PNP/2-NT). From the absorption spectra, it is clear that both PA and PNP have absorptions in the region at 375 nm (), which also happens to be the excitation wavelength during the present study. It can be noted 2-NT does not absorb at 375 nm. Therefore, the luminescence quenching observed in the case of PA and PNP, may be due to the absorption of the excitation energy.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out in oxygen atmosphere (flow rate = 40 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 10 °C/min). The first weight loss of ∼13.4% observed in the temperature range 30–130 °C for compound 1, [{[Ca6(H2O)18]­[Ag6(mna)6]2}­·[Ag6(H2mna)6]­·20H2O], corresponds to the loss of the lattice and coordinated water molecules (calc. 12.3%). The decomposition of 1 appears to start after 285 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). In the case of compound 2 {[Sr3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·12H2O}, the initial weight loss of ∼17.8% in the temperature range of 30–120 °C corresponds to loss of the 12 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 18.0%). Compound 2 starts to decompose after 310 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The first weight loss of ∼14.2% observed in the temperature range 30–120 °C for compound 3, {[Ba3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, corresponds to the loss of the 8 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 14.3%). The second weight loss in the temperature range of 270–560 °C is due to the loss of the mna ligands (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The final products after the TGA analysis for all the compounds 1–3 were found to be metallic Ag (JCPDS: 87-0720) and the corresponding sulfates of alkaline earth metal ions, CaSO4 (JCPDS: 72-0916), SrSO4 (JCPDS: 89-0954), and BaSO4 (JCPDS: 83-2053), respectively (Supporting Information, Figure S24).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out in oxygen atmosphere (flow rate = 40 mL/min) in the temperature range 30-800 °C (heating rate = 10 °C/min). The first weight loss of ~13.4% observed in the temperature range 30-130 °C for compound 1, [{[Ca6(H2O)18][Ag6(mna)6]2}⋅[Ag6(H2mna)6]⋅20H2O], corresponds to the loss of the lattice and coordinated water molecules (calc. 12.3%). The decomposition of 1 appears to start after 285 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). In the case of compound 2 {[Sr3(H2O)10][Ag6(mna)6]⋅12H2O}, the initial weight loss of ~17.8% in the temperature range of 30-120 °C corresponds to loss of the 12 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 18.0%). Compound 2 starts to decompose after 310 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The first weight loss of ~14.2% observed in the temperature range 30-120 °C for compound 3, {[Ba3(H2O)10][Ag6(mna)6]⋅8H2O}, corresponds to the loss of the 8 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 14.3%). The second weight loss in the temperature range of 270-560 °C is due to the loss of the mna ligands (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The final products after the TGA analysis for all the compounds 1-3 were found to be metallic Ag (JCPDS: 87-0720) and the corresponding sulfates of alkaline earth metal ions, CaSO4 (JCPDS: 72-0916), SrSO4 (JCPDS: 89-0954), and BaSO4 (JCPDS: 83-2053), respectively (Supporting Information, Figure S24).

elements.content: A room temperature, sequential synthetic strategy was employed to prepare three new compounds based on hexanuclear anionic metalloligand, [Ag6(mna)6]6–, and alkaline earth elements (Ca, Sr, and Ba). According to the HSAB principle, softer N and S atoms of mna ligand are connected to soft Ag+, and harder oxygen atom is coordinated to hard alkaline earth elements. The compounds exhibit two (Ba) and three-dimensionally (Ca/Sr) extended structures. The compounds are electron-rich due to the presence of the mna ligand, Ag+ (d10) and alkaline earth metal ions, which has been employed gainfully to detect electron deficient nitroaromatics by fluorimetric methods. The strong luminescence behavor of the compounds were exploited for the detection of hazardous nitroaromatics explosives. The quenching of the luminescence in the presence of nitroaromatics was explained using the experimental observation and theoretical calculations. Our continuing investigations suggest that the use of the metalloligand of the type used in the present study can be made to bind with many other hard acids such as lanthanides, and work toward this goal is presently underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A room temperature, sequential synthetic strategy was employed to prepare three new compounds based on hexanuclear anionic metalloligand, [Ag6(mna)6]6-, and alkaline earth elements (Ca, Sr, and Ba). According to the HSAB principle, softer N and S atoms of mna ligand are connected to soft Ag+, and harder oxygen atom is coordinated to hard alkaline earth elements. The compounds exhibit two (Ba) and three-dimensionally (Ca/Sr) extended structures. The compounds are electron-rich due to the presence of the mna ligand, Ag+ (d10) and alkaline earth metal ions, which has been employed gainfully to detect electron deficient nitroaromatics by fluorimetric methods. The strong luminescence behavor of the compounds were exploited for the detection of hazardous nitroaromatics explosives. The quenching of the luminescence in the presence of nitroaromatics was explained using the experimental observation and theoretical calculations. Our continuing investigations suggest that the use of the metalloligand of the type used in the present study can be made to bind with many other hard acids such as lanthanides, and work toward this goal is presently underway.

(Solution A) A mixture of AgNO3 (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (0.031 g, 0.2 mmol) in 2 mL of water was sonicated at room temperature for 20 min. The pale yellow precipitate that formed was dissolved by the addition of few drops of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution.

Preparation of Alkaline Earth Metal Ion Solution

(Solution B) Ca­(NO3)2­·4H2O (0.047 g, 0.2 mmol)/Sr­(NO3)2 (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) or Ba­(NO3)2 (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) was taken in a 2 mL water/ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1) for the synthesis of the respective compound.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ag6(mna)6]6- Metalloligand

(Solution A) A mixture of AgNO3 (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (0.031 g, 0.2 mmol) in 2 mL of water was sonicated at room temperature for 20 min. The pale yellow precipitate that formed was dissolved by the addition of few drops of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution.

Preparation of Alkaline Earth Metal Ion Solution

(Solution B) Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.047 g, 0.2 mmol)/Sr(NO3)2 (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) or Ba(NO3)2 (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) was taken in a 2 mL water/ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1) for the synthesis of the respective compound.

cln_elements.content:
The UV–Vis absorption spectra of compounds have been recorded at room temperature in the solid state. All the compounds exhibit absorption bands in the region of 200–500 nm (Supporting Information, Figure S14). The various observed bands correspond to the intraligand π → π* transitions of the mna ligand. Similar absorption bands have been observed for the free H2mna ligand also (Supporting Information, Figure S14). We have also made estimation of the optical band gap in the compounds, which suggested band gap energy values lie in the range of 2.64–2.76 eV (Supporting Information, Figure S15). The band gap energies as determined by the Tauc plots, are very close to that for the metalloligand [Ag6(mna)6]6– (2.73 eV) and free H2mna ligand (2.75 eV). This implies that the electronic states of the compounds are close to the metalloligand, which could be due to the closed shell electronic configuration of the divalent alkaline earth metal ions.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out in oxygen atmosphere (flow rate = 40 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 10 °C/min). The first weight loss of ∼13.4% observed in the temperature range 30–130 °C for compound 1, [{[Ca6(H2O)18]­[Ag6(mna)6]2}­·[Ag6(H2mna)6]­·20H2O], corresponds to the loss of the lattice and coordinated water molecules (calc. 12.3%). The decomposition of 1 appears to start after 285 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). In the case of compound 2 {[Sr3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·12H2O}, the initial weight loss of ∼17.8% in the temperature range of 30–120 °C corresponds to loss of the 12 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 18.0%). Compound 2 starts to decompose after 310 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The first weight loss of ∼14.2% observed in the temperature range 30–120 °C for compound 3, {[Ba3(H2O)10]­[Ag6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, corresponds to the loss of the 8 lattice water molecules and 10 coordinated water molecules (calc. 14.3%). The second weight loss in the temperature range of 270–560 °C is due to the loss of the mna ligands (Supporting Information, Figure S2). The final products after the TGA analysis for all the compounds 1–3 were found to be metallic Ag (JCPDS: 87-0720) and the corresponding sulfates of alkaline earth metal ions, CaSO4 (JCPDS: 72-0916), SrSO4 (JCPDS: 89-0954), and BaSO4 (JCPDS: 83-2053), respectively (Supporting Information, Figure S24).

This implies that the electronic states of the compounds are close to the metalloligand, which could be due to the closed shell electronic configuration of the divalent alkaline earth metal ions.

The second weight loss in the temperature range of 270-560 °C is due to the loss of the mna ligands (Supporting Information, Figure S2).
